segment.source: Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker (Windows 10)
segment.target: Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic explains the AppLocker path rule condition, the advantages and disadvantages, and how it is applied.
segment.target: This topic explains the AppLocker path rule condition, the advantages and disadvantages, and how it is applied.

segment.source: Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker
segment.target: Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic explains the AppLocker path rule condition, the advantages and disadvantages, and how it is applied.
segment.target: This topic explains the AppLocker path rule condition, the advantages and disadvantages, and how it is applied.

segment.source: The path condition identifies an application by its location in the file system of the computer or on the network.
segment.target: The path condition identifies an application by its location in the file system of the computer or on the network.

segment.source: When creating a rule that uses a deny action, path conditions are less secure than publisher and file hash conditions for preventing access to a file because a user could easily copy the file to a different location than the location specified in the rule.
segment.target: When creating a rule that uses a deny action, path conditions are less secure than publisher and file hash conditions for preventing access to a file because a user could easily copy the file to a different location than the location specified in the rule.

segment.source: Because path rules specify locations within the file system, you should ensure that there are no subdirectories that are writable by non-administrators.
segment.target: Because path rules specify locations within the file system, you should ensure that there are no subdirectories that are writable by non-administrators.

segment.source: For example, if you create a path rule for C: with the allow action, any file under that location will be allowed to run, including within users' profiles.
segment.target: For example, if you create a path rule for C: with the allow action, any file under that location will be allowed to run, including within users' profiles.

segment.source: The following table describes the advantages and disadvantages of the path condition.
segment.target: The following table describes the advantages and disadvantages of the path condition.

segment.source: Path condition advantages
segment.target: Path condition advantages

segment.source: Path condition disadvantages
segment.target: Path condition disadvantages

segment.source: You can easily control many folders or a single file.
segment.target: You can easily control many folders or a single file.

segment.source: You can use the asterisk (*) as a wildcard character within path rules.
segment.target: You can use the asterisk (*) as a wildcard character within path rules.

segment.source: It might be less secure if a rule that is configured to use a folder path contains subfolders that are writable by non-administrators.
segment.target: It might be less secure if a rule that is configured to use a folder path contains subfolders that are writable by non-administrators.

segment.source: You must specify the full path to a file or folder when creating path rules so that the rule will be properly enforced.
segment.target: You must specify the full path to a file or folder when creating path rules so that the rule will be properly enforced.

segment.source: AppLocker does not enforce rules that specify paths with short names.
segment.target: AppLocker does not enforce rules that specify paths with short names.

segment.source: You should always specify the full path to a file or folder when creating path rules so that the rule will be properly enforced.
segment.target: You should always specify the full path to a file or folder when creating path rules so that the rule will be properly enforced.

segment.source: The asterisk () wildcard character can be used within Path field.
segment.target: The asterisk () wildcard character can be used within Path field.

segment.source: The asterisk () character used by itself represents any path.
segment.target: The asterisk () character used by itself represents any path.

segment.source: When combined with any string value, the rule is limited to the path of the file and all the files under that path.
segment.target: When combined with any string value, the rule is limited to the path of the file and all the files under that path.

segment.source: For example, %ProgramFiles%Internet Explorer indicates that all files and subfolders within the Internet Explorer folder will be affected by the rule.
segment.target: For example, %ProgramFiles%Internet Explorer indicates that all files and subfolders within the Internet Explorer folder will be affected by the rule.

segment.source: AppLocker uses path variables for well-known directories in Windows.
segment.target: AppLocker uses path variables for well-known directories in Windows.

segment.source: Path variables are not environment variables.
segment.target: Path variables are not environment variables.

segment.source: The AppLocker engine can only interpret AppLocker path variables.
segment.target: The AppLocker engine can only interpret AppLocker path variables.

segment.source: The following table details these path variables.
segment.target: The following table details these path variables.

segment.source: Windows directory or drive
segment.target: Windows directory or drive

segment.source: AppLocker path variable
segment.target: AppLocker path variable

segment.source: Windows environment variable
segment.target: Windows environment variable

segment.source: Windows
segment.target: Windows

segment.source: %WINDIR%
segment.target: %WINDIR%

segment.source: %SystemRoot%
segment.target: %SystemRoot%

segment.source: System32
segment.target: System32

segment.source: %SYSTEM32%
segment.target: %SYSTEM32%

segment.source: %SystemDirectory%
segment.target: %SystemDirectory%

segment.source: Windows installation directory
segment.target: Windows installation directory

segment.source: %OSDRIVE%
segment.target: %OSDRIVE%

segment.source: %SystemDrive%
segment.target: %SystemDrive%

segment.source: Program Files
segment.target: Program Files

segment.source: %PROGRAMFILES%
segment.target: %PROGRAMFILES%

segment.source: %ProgramFiles% and %ProgramFiles(x86)%
segment.target: %ProgramFiles% and %ProgramFiles(x86)%

segment.source: Removable media (for example, CD or DVD)
segment.target: Removable media (for example, CD or DVD)

segment.source: %REMOVABLE%
segment.target: %REMOVABLE%

segment.source: Removable storage device (for example, USB flash drive)
segment.target: Removable storage device (for example, USB flash drive)

segment.source: %HOT%
segment.target: %HOT%

segment.source: For an overview of the three types of AppLocker rule conditions and explanations of the advantages and disadvantages of each, see Understanding AppLocker rule condition types.
segment.target: For an overview of the three types of AppLocker rule conditions and explanations of the advantages and disadvantages of each, see Understanding AppLocker rule condition types.
